case_name: Sammbhu Nath Jha v. Kedar Prasad

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 30 of 1969 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 12th August 1968 of the Patna High Court in Original Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 30 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 30 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th August, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Original Criminal Misc

facts.text: Sammbhu Nath Jha along with two others was found guilty of contempt of court by the Patna High Court but let off with a warning due to technical nature.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave by Sammbhu Nath Jha who along with two others has been found by the Patna High Court to be guilty of contempt of court. In view of the fact that the contempt,

facts.text: On January 2, 1966, Lachho Paswan lodged a report with police that Kedar Prasad abused him and his brother Dwarka Paswan while going to Jamui market.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1966 a report was lodged with the police by Lachho Paswan that when he and his brother Dwarka Paswan were going to Jamui market, Kedar Prasad respondent abused them.

facts.text: Kedar Prasad exhorted others to assault Dwarka Paswan, Arjun Pandey thrust Saif in his chest, resulting in death on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: Kedar Prasad also exhorted others to assult Dwarka Paswan. An assault was then made upon Dwarka Paswan and he was surrounded. Arjun Pandey thrust Saif in the chest of Dwarka Paswan, as a result

facts.text: Motive for assault was that Lachho and Dwarka Paswan voted against Kedar Prasad in election to office of Mukhia.

anchor.surface_text: of which he died on the spot. The motive for the assault was stated to be that Lachho Paswan and Dwarka Paswan had voted against Kedar Prasad in the election to the office of Mukhia.

facts.text: Police investigated and submitted charge sheet under sections 148 and 302 read with 149 IPC against a number of persons, but not against Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey.

anchor.surface_text: The police on the basis of that report investigated the case and submitted a charge sheet for offences under sections 148 and 302 read with section 149 I.P.C. against a number of persons. No charge

facts.text: Committing magistrate ordered Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey to be summoned as accused for May 15, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: During the course of commitment proceedings, the committing magistrate ordered that Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey be summoned for May 15, 1966 as accused.

facts.text: Revision petitions by Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey against summoning order dismissed by Additional Sessions Judge, Monghyr on May 5, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey filed revision petitions against the order of the committing magistrate, but the same was dismissed by the Additional Sessions Judge, Monghyr is per order dated May

facts.text: On September 18, 1967, Assistant District Prosecutor filed application in magistrate court for withdrawal of case against Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey.

anchor.surface_text: After the dismissal of the revision petition, an application was filed by the Assistant District Prosecutor on September 18, 1967 in the Court of the learned magistrate for withdrawal of the case

facts.text: Magistrate dismissed withdrawal application on October 6, 1967, observing it as abuse of process.

anchor.surface_text: against Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey oil the ground that it was inexpedient for State and public policy to prosecute them. After hearing the counsel for the complainant and others, the committing

facts.text: Two revision petitions filed against October 6, 1967 order: one by State of Bihar, one by Abani Kumar Mandal, admitted by High Court on November 30, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Two revision petitions were filed against the above order dated October 6, 1967. One of the revision petitions was filed by the State of Bihar and the other was filed by one Abani Kumar Mandal.

facts.text: On March 12, 1968, Governor of Bihar appointed Commission of Inquiry under section 3 of Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1952 consisting of Shri T. L. Venkatarama Aiyer to inquire into charges against 14 persons including Hasibur Rahman.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the above mentioned criminal revision petitions, the Governor of Bihar as per notification dated March -L864 SupCI/72 12, 1968 appointed a Commission of Inquiry consisting

facts.text: Hasibur Rahman held office of Minister from March 16, 1967 to January 28, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: One of the persons against whom inquiry was ordered was Shri Hasibur Rahman who had held the office of Minister during the period from March 16, 1967 to January 28, 1968.

facts.text: Allegation No. J-4 in Commission notification detailed Hasibur Rahman's interference in the case against Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey.

anchor.surface_text: Allegation No. J-4 which was the subject of inquiry against Shri Hasibur Rahman was asunder Shri Kedar Prasad Sinha and Shri Arjun Pandey were facing prosecution along with nine others in a seri

facts.text: Notification appointing Commission published in Bihar Gazette Extraordinary dated March 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The notification relating to the appointment of the Commission of Inquiry along with the schedule containing the different allegations was published in the Bihar Gazette Extraordinary dated March

facts.text: On March 12, 1968, appellant Sammbhu Nath Jha, a minister of Bihar, gave copy of notification including schedule to press for publication.

anchor.surface_text: The same day the appellant, who was one of the ministers of Bihar, gave for publication to the press a copy of the notification, including the schedule of allegations.

facts.text: Notification with schedule published in Searchlight of Patna on March 13, 14, and 15, 1968; Allegation J-4 on March 14, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The said notification along with the schedule of allegations was published in the Searchlight of Patna in issues dated March 13, March 14 and March 15 of 1968. Allegation No. J-4 relating to the

facts.text: On March 25, 1968, Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey filed application for contempt proceedings against 25 persons including appellant as respondent No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: Application dated March 25, 1968 was thereafter filed by Kedar Prasad and Arjun Pandey for initiating contempt of court proceedings against 25 persons, including the State of Bihar, the Chief,

facts.text: Patna High Court held 22 out of 25 persons guilty of contempt, including appellant for handing over material to press.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that there is no contempt of court in the present case.

issues.text: Whether the appellant committed contempt of court by handing over the notification issued under section 3 of the Commissions of Inquiry Act, including the schedule of allegations, to the press for publication during the pendency of criminal revision petitions in the High Court

Whether the notification appointing the Commission of Inquiry under section 3 of the Commissions of Inquiry Act, including the schedule containing allegations, must be published in the Official Gazette as an imperative requirement

Whether the subject matter of allegation No. J-4 before the Commission of Inquiry (misuse of official position by the Minister) is identical to the question in the pending criminal revision petitions (whether the magistrate's order dismissing withdrawal application was contrary to law)
Whether setting up or continuing a Commission of Inquiry into matters overlapping with pending court proceedings constitutes contempt of court
Whether the publication tends to interfere with the due course of justice in pending proceedings

arguments.claim: Publication of allegation No. J-4 related to a matter which was the subject matter of criminal revision petitions in the High Court and had the result of interfering with the course of justice and prejudicing the mankind against the two applicants

holdings.text: The present is not a fit case wherein action should be taken for contempt of court.

anchor.surface_text: After giving the matter our consideration, we are of the opinion that the present is not a fit case wherein action should be taken for contempt of court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Publication was entire official notification required by statute; subjects of commission inquiry and pending revisions distinct; no tendency to interfere with justice; at most technical contempt warranting no action.

holdings.text: The notification appointing a commission of inquiry must be published in the official gazette. It is an imperative requirement and cannot be dispensed with.

anchor.surface_text: Plain reading of the above subsection makes it manifest that the notification appointing a commission of inquiry must be published in the official gazette. It is an, imperative requirement and cann

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of section 3(1) of Commissions of Inquiry Act mandates publication in Official Gazette for validity and publicity.

holdings.text: The schedule containing the various allegations in the present case was a part of the notification dated March 12, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The schedule containing the various allegations in the present case was a part of the notification dated March 12, 1968 and specified definite matters of public importance which were to be inquire

holdings.reasoning_summary: Schedule annexed specifies matters of public importance for inquiry, integral to notification under s.3.

holdings.text: The two matters were distinct and separate and not identical.

anchor.surface_text: The subject matter of the inquiry before the Commission as set forth in allegation No. J-4 was whether there was any misuse of official position on the part of Shri Hasibur Rahman when he directed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commission inquired into minister's misuse of position directing withdrawal; revisions concerned magistrate's order refusing withdrawal as contrary to law.

holdings.text: It may be that some of the matters which were connected with the criminal revision petitions were the subject of inquiry by the commission of inquiry, but that would not attract liability for contempt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Connection between matters insufficient for contempt without tendency to interfere with justice.

holdings.text: The setting up of the commission of inquiry by the State Government or the continuation of the inquiry by the commission would not constitute contempt of court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Dalmia case: commissions conduct non-judicial inquiries, do not usurp court functions even with overlap.

holdings.text: In our view the judgment of the High Court cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the judgment of the High Court cannot be sus- tained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in finding contempt based on incorrect assumption no statutory duty to publish allegations; publication lawful and no interference.

holdings.text: Ordinarily a court will not initiate proceedings for committal for contempt where there is a mere technical contempt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts exercise judicial restraint considering circumstances; cited from Re P.C. Sen.

anchor.surface_text: is a companytempt of companyrt Reg. v. Gray 1 . The law of companytempt as observed by this Court in the case of E. M. S. Namboodripad v. T. N. Nambiar 2  stems from the right of the companyrts to punish by imprisonment or fines persons guilty of words or acts which either obstruct or tend to obstruct the administration of justice. This right is exercised in India by all companyrts when companytempt is companymitted in facie curaie and by the superior companyrts on their own behalf or on behalf of companyrts subordinate to them even if companymitted outside the companyrts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Any act done or writing published which is calculated to bring a court or judge into contempt or to lower his authority or to interfere with the due course of justice or the lawful process of the courts is a contempt of court

precedents.citation: E. M. S. Namboodripad v. T. N. Nambiar 2

anchor.surface_text: The law of companytempt as observed by this Court in the case of E. M. S. Namboodripad v. T. N. Nambiar 2  stems from the right of the companyrts to punish by imprisonment or fines persons guilty of words or acts which either obstruct or tend to obstruct the administration of justice. This right is exercised in India by all companyrts when companytempt is companymitted in facie curaie and by the superior companyrts on their own behalf or on behalf of companyrts subordinate to them even if companymitted outside the companyrts. Formerly, it was regarded as inherent in the powers of a Court of Record and number by the Constitution of India, it is a part of the powers of the Supreme Court and the High Courts.

precedents.case_name: E. M. S. Namboodripad v. T. N. Nambiar
precedents.cited_proposition: The law of contempt stems from the right of the courts to punish by imprisonment or fines persons guilty of words or acts which either obstruct or tend to obstruct the administration of justice

anchor.surface_text: The matter was also dealt with by this Court Re P. C. Sen 3  and it was observed Contempt by speech or writing may be by scandalising the Court itself, or by abusing parties to actions, or by prejudicing mankind in favour of or against a party before the cause is heard. It is incumbent upon Courts of justice to preserve their proceedings from being misrepresented, for prejudicing the minds of the public against persons companycerned as parties in causes before the cause is finally heard has pernicious companysequences.

precedents.cited_proposition: Contempt by speech or writing may be by scandalising the Court itself, or by abusing parties to actions, or by prejudicing mankind in favour of or against a party before the cause is heard
precedents.cited_holding: Speeches or writings misrepresenting the proceedings of the Court or prejudicing the public for or against a party or involving reflections on parties to a proceeding amount to contempt

precedents.citation: Debi Prasad Sharma and Ors. v. The King-Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in the above cited case was placed upon the following observations of the Judicial Committee in the case of Debi Prasad Sharma and Ors. v. The King-Emperor 1 . .lm15 . . . the test applied by the Board which heard the reference, was whether the words companyplained of were in the circumstances calculated to obstruct or interfere with the companyrse of justice and the due administration of law.

precedents.cited_proposition: The test is whether the words complained of were in the circumstances calculated to obstruct or interfere with the course of justice and the due administration of law

anchor.surface_text: It has also to be borne in mind, as observed in Re P. C. Sen 2 , that ordinarily a companyrt will number initiate proceedings for companymitment for companytempt where there is a mere technical companytempt. This Court referred in the above companytext to tile observations of Jenkins, C.J., in Legal Remembrancer v. Matilal Ghose and Others 3  that proceedings for companytempt should be initiated with utmost reserve and numbercourt in the due discharge of its duty can afford to disregard them.

precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinarily a court will not initiate proceedings for commitment for contempt where there is a mere technical contempt

precedents.citation: Legal Remembrancer v. Matilal Ghose and Others 3

anchor.surface_text: This Court referred in the above companytext to tile observations of Jenkins, C.J., in Legal Remembrancer v. Matilal Ghose and Others 3  that proceedings for companytempt should be initiated with utmost reserve and numbercourt in the due discharge of its duty can afford to disregard them. It would follow from the above that the companyrts have power to take action against a person who does ,in act or publishes a writing which is calculated to bring a companyrt or judge into companytempt or to lower his authority or to obstruct the due companyrse of justice or due administration of law.

precedents.cited_proposition: Proceedings for contempt should be initiated with utmost reserve and no court in the due discharge of its duty can afford to disregard them

precedents.citation: Jagannath Rao v. State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Jagannath Rao v. State of Orissa 1  the appellant had challenged a numberification issued under section 3 of the Commissions of Inquiry Act appointing a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into certain allegations against persons who had held the offices of Chief Ministers and ministers in Orissa. An argument was advanced in that case that one of the items of charges which were to be inquired into bay the companymission was the subject matter of an appeal pending in the High Court.

precedents.case_name: Jagannath Rao v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Setting up of a Commission of Inquiry or continuation of the inquiry by the Commission would not be tantamount to contempt of court even if some matters overlap with pending court proceedings
precedents.cited_holding: The inquiry and the investigation by the Commission do not amount to usurpation of the function of the courts of law

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1  that the inquiry cannot be looked upon as a judicial inquiry and the order ultimately passed cannot be enforced proprio vigore. The inquiry and the investigation by the Commission do number therefore amount to usurpation of the function of the companyrts of law. The scope of the trial by the Courts of law and the Commission of Inquiry is altogether different.

precedents.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: The inquiry by a Commission of Inquiry cannot be looked upon as a judicial inquiry and the order ultimately passed cannot be enforced proprio vigore

edges.explanation: Issue i1 concerns whether contempt was committed via publication/notification on pending proceedings, directly addressing the concept c7 of contempt by comments on pending proceedings.
Contempt issue i1 addresses the Tendency to Interfere Test (c8) as part of determining contempt
Determining contempt in i1 requires assessing tendency to interfere in i5
i2 requires application of Section 3 concept c5

To determine if setting up/continuing a Commission of Inquiry overlapping pending court proceedings constitutes contempt, the court must ascertain the true nature and character (pith and substance) of the commission as non-judicial.
Issue i5 directly formulates the question of whether the publication tends to interfere with due course of justice, matching the core condition in concept c7 for contempt.
Issue i5 on whether publication tends to interfere directly addresses the Tendency to Interfere Test (c8)
Resolving i5 requires application of the Tendency to Interfere Test defined in c8
